awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Extremum Seeking Control of Wind Turbines and Wind Farms
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the introduction of a new wind farm control strategy that is expected to increase the power generated by a typical wind farm by 3-10%.  Wind farm owners and operators face continuous pressure to reduce the price per megawatt-hour of the grid energy that they produce.  Improving the energy yield of existing wind farms by optimizing array yaw angles (known as “wake steering”) may lower the cost of energy, increase our customer’s profits, and promote greater wind energy penetration in domestic and global grid energy markets.  

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop a new model-free approach to maximizing the annual energy produced by wind farms. On most wind farms, the turbines are operated independently, relying only on their individual wind sensors to determine the wind direction and to make control decisions to orient themselves to generate maximum power. The proposed approach will allow arrays of turbines to work together to minimize losses by steering the wakes of upstream turbines away from the downwind rows, increasing net power production. While this technique has been proposed in the past, the methods employed have relied on control algorithms that use models to determine the key operating parameters. Since every wind farm is different, those parameters must be tuned on-site using expensive and time-consuming calibration campaigns. Moreover, as the turbines age, those parameters can end up far from their optimal values. The new proposed scheme takes a different, model-free approach that may eliminate the need for parameter calibration while ensuring that the array continuously operates at its peak performance even as atmospheric and other environmental conditions change and the physical conditions of the turbines deteriorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to address the critical challenge of enhancing energy yield in wind farms through wake steering, a method of coordinating wind turbines to maximize energy production and minimize wake effects. Traditional wind farms operate turbines individually, but recent advancements suggest that coordinated control, including wake steering, can significantly improve overall efficiency.

The study utilized the Log-of-Power Proportional-Integral Extremum Seeking Control (LP-PIESC) algorithm in simulated wind farms to explore the effects of turbine yaw optimization on net power gain and fatigue loads. This innovative algorithm was developed to iteratively adjust yaw angles seeking to maximize power output between two or more turbines. State-of-the-art wake steering algorithms are dominated by modeling assumptions that often do not hold in practice and models that cannot capture all the relevant effects without frequent calibration. LP-PIESC is a control scheme that is less reliant on models and can be used to increase wind farm power yield by continuously optimizing array performance through wake steering.

The research included simulations using NREL's FAST.Farm and OpenFAST tools, focusing on the NREL 5 MW Reference wind turbine and various wake steering scenarios. The simulations provided insights into wake deflection, power gains, and load impacts, highlighting the nuanced relationship between yaw misalignment, wind conditions, and turbine spacing.

In FAST.Farm simulations with two inline turbines, the implementation of the LP-PIESC algorithm demonstrated an average power increase of 8.5%, with minimal impact on fatigue loading, indicating a promising method for enhancing wind farm performance.

Field application was conceptualized using data from the Haystack Wind Farm in Nebraska, which consists of Siemens Gamesa 5.0-145 turbines. This turbine, rated at 5 MW, has a similar cut-in, rated, and cut-out wind speeds, and a similar power curve as the NREL 5 MW Reference turbine, which makes it an ideal candidate for modeling in FAST.Farm. Site wind data was extracted using publicly available data from USGS, NOAA, and ECMWF. A subset of four turbines were simulated in FAST.Farm using the frequency distribution wind data from publicly available sources. A baseline energy output was calculated by simulating one year of wind data on the four-turbine array. The LP-PIESC algorithm was then applied to the four-turbine array and the mean instantaneous power of all four turbines were summed over each simulation to determine the total power output for each scenario. This resulted in annual energy outputs of 66,638 MWh with the algorithm disabled, and 69,583 MWh with the algorithm enabled. With LP-PIESC enabled, the four-turbine cluster experienced a 4.4% increase in annual energy production.

Significant findings from the project include:

Optimizing Wake Interactions: The study confirmed that wake steering can substantially increase power output while maintaining structural integrity. By redirecting wakes away from downstream turbines, the overall energy production of the wind farm can be significantly enhanced.

Algorithm Effectiveness: Extremum seeking control algorithms maximizing the logarithm of selected cluster within a wind farm are effective for dynamically adjusting yaw angles to optimize power production. Implementation in simulations indicated notable increases in annual energy production, demonstrating its potential for real-world application.

Load Implications: Analysis of the turbine loads revealed that while wake steering could increase certain loads, the strategy overall could mitigate negative effects, especially on downstream turbines. This suggests that with careful implementation, wake steering can improve energy production without compromising turbine longevity.

Commercial Development and Stakeholder Engagement: The project involved stakeholder engagement to align technological advancements with industry needs. Efforts were made to develop a robust brand for the technology and secure partnerships for future commercial development.

Training and Professional Development: The project provided opportunities for training in relevant software and methodologies, contributing to the skill development of those involved.

The promising results pave the way for further exploration and application of wake steering techniques in the wind energy sector, with the potential to yield substantial benefits in terms of performance and efficiency.
